prompt.transcript:
28yo, G3P2 (1x SVD, 1x LSCS for FTP), 31+2, BMI 29, Rh+ve

Issues:
Antenatal diagnosis of placenta percreta with bladder invasion
Previous LSCS and possible placenta accreta in previous pregnancy
High risk of major haemorrhage and need for multidisciplinary management

Background:
Placenta percreta diagnosed on USS at 20 weeks, confirmed on MRI
Previous pregnancy complicated by placenta accreta, requiring PPH management and blood transfusion
G&S tests normal, FBC and coagulation profile within normal limits
Multidisciplinary team (MDT) discussion and planning with obstetrics, anaesthetics, and urology

Assessment:
High risk of severe haemorrhage at delivery, requiring careful planning and management
Need for level 3 maternity unit with available blood products and surgical expertise

Plan:
Elective LSCS and possible hysterectomy at 34-35 weeks, depending on fetal and maternal condition
Intraoperative cell salvage and blood transfusion to be available
Urology input and possible cystoscopy for bladder repair
Postnatal care to include monitoring for haemorrhage and infection, and thromboprophylaxis
Regular MDT meetings to review and update management plan

Discussion:
Patient counselled regarding risks and management options, including possible hysterectomy
Patient to be aware of signs of haemorrhage and infection, and to seek immediate medical attention if concerned
Consideration for postnatal contraception and family planning options to be discussed post-delivery

Exam:
BP: 120/80 mmHg, HR: 90 bpm, Temp: 36.5°C, SpO2: 98% RA
Abdomen soft, non-tender, no palpable masses
Fetal movement and heart rate normal

Investigations:
USS: Placenta percreta with bladder invasion, fetal growth restriction (FGR) noted
MRI: Confirmed placenta percreta with bladder invasion, no other abnormalities seen
FBC: Hb 105 g/L, MCV 85 fL, Platelets 250 x10⁹/L
Coagulation profile: Normal INR and APTT

RECOMMENDATION:
Immediate Management:
Admit to level 3 maternity unit for close monitoring and management
Corticosteroids for fetal lung maturation, if delivery prior to 34 weeks
Regular USS and monitoring for signs of haemorrhage and fetal distress

Monitoring & Follow-Up:
Regular MDT meetings to review and update management plan
USS and FBC monitoring, with consideration for delivery if signs of haemorrhage or fetal distress
Postnatal care to include monitoring for haemorrhage and infection, and thromboprophylaxis
